dcterms:title: The Woman Who Didn't : ELTeC edition
dcterms:creator: Cross, Victoria (1868-1952)
dcterms:publisher: COST Action "Distant Reading for European Literary History" (CA16204)
dct:description: A late-19th-century romantic drama about a young British officer who falls passionately in love with Eurydice Williamson, a beautiful, intellectual woman he meets on an eastern voyage. Their intense mutual attraction is checked when he discovers she is married; Eurydice, convinced that marriage is a sacred obligation despite her husband's indifference, refuses divorce or an affair. The narrative follows the man's struggle with desire, conscience, and self-restraint as he pursues a chaste friendship meant to reform him, while Eurydice upholds duty and moral principle. The plot culminates in the husband's unexpected return, underscoring themes of sacrifice, honor, and social convention.
dcat:theme: Social critique of late-Victorian gender roles

mainCharacters.name: Unnamed narrator (male officer)
mainCharacters.profile: An English army officer recently returned from India, he is the first-person narrator whose life is upended by an intense love for Eurydice. Torn between passion and a code of honour, he attempts dissipation, reform, and self-control while navigating conscience and social expectations.

mainCharacters.name: Eurydice Williamson (Mrs. Williamson)
mainCharacters.profile: A striking, intelligent, and morally resolute woman who captivates the narrator with her beauty and intellect. Married to Major Williamson, she nonetheless refuses divorce or infidelity on principle, treating marriage as a sacred duty even amid emotional suffering.

mainCharacters.name: Dickinson
mainCharacters.profile: The narrator's convivial friend and companionship figure, worldly and pleasure-seeking, often offering cynical or teasing commentary. He serves as a foil to the narrator's moral struggles, embodying ease with vice and social frivolity.

mainCharacters.name: Major Williamson
mainCharacters.profile: Eurydice's husband, at first absent during much of the story and later returning unexpectedly; he is portrayed as emotionally distant and unfaithful in spirit rather than overtly cruel. His presence and Eurydice's loyalty to the marriage vow create the central moral obstacle for the narrator.
